slides.title: Data Governance Domains and Graph DB Benefits

cells.text: Core Data Governance Domains
Governance Area
Governance Purpose
Graph DB Benefit
Data Ownership & Stewardship
Defines accountability for data assets and their lifecycle.
Graph models link assets directly to owners and stewards, making responsibility easy to trace and visualize.
Data Quality Management
Ensures accuracy, completeness, consistency, and timeliness of data.
Relationships in the graph can expose quality issues in context (e.g., upstream dependencies, affected reports).
Metadata Management
Captures, organizes, and maintains data definitions, lineage, and context.
Graphs provide a flexible, schema-agnostic structure ideal for capturing evolving metadata and interconnections.
Data Lineage & Traceability
Tracks the origin, movement, and transformation of data across systems.
Graph traversal enables fast, intuitive lineage and impact analysis across complex data flows.
Master & Reference Data Management
Establishes authoritative sources and consistent values across domains.
Graph relationships reveal hierarchies, duplicates, and inconsistencies across domains.
Data Classification & Cataloging
Categorizes data by sensitivity, criticality, and business relevance.
Graph tags and node types allow dynamic classification and faceted search across datasets.
Access & Security Control
Manages user permissions, encryption, and secure access protocols.
Graph structures can model permissions and roles tied to specific data objects and paths.
Policy & Standards Management
Documents and enforces rules for data usage, retention, and compliance.
Policies can be linked to assets, systems, and owners, making enforcement paths transparent.
Regulatory Compliance & Auditability
Aligns data practices with legal and industry regulations (e.g., HIPAA, GDPR).
Graphs show data flow, use, and ownership, helping demonstrate regulatory alignment.
Data Architecture & Integration
Aligns data models and integration strategies with enterprise systems.
Graph databases naturally integrate siloed metadata and models through relationship mapping.
Operational Execution Components
Governance Area
Governance Purpose
Graph DB Benefit
Governance Operating Model
Defines roles, responsibilities, decision rights, and escalation paths.
Graph can visually and structurally represent governance roles, responsibilities, and their data domains.
Issue Management & Resolution
Tracks and remediates data-related problems and policy violations.
Relationships reveal impact and root cause across related assets and domains.
Metrics & Performance Monitoring
Measures data governance effectiveness and asset health.
Graphs can aggregate metrics across nodes and relationships to visualize health and governance gaps.
Training & Change Management
Builds data literacy and promotes adherence to governance practices.
Graph-based visuals help communicate complex relationships to business users more clearly.
Technology Enablement
Utilizes tools for cataloging, lineage, quality, policy enforcement, etc.
Many modern tools (e.g., Collibra, DataHub) use graphs under the hood for powerful capabilities.
Business Glossary & Ontology Management
Maintains shared vocabularies and taxonomies for enterprise understanding.
Graph structure supports hierarchies, synonyms, and contextual links between terms and assets.
Data Lifecycle Management
Oversees data from creation and usage to archival and disposal.
Graphs can track each lifecycle stage across systems and relate it to policies, owners, and usage.
